questions.text:
A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of increasing generalized fatigue and severe pruritus. He has hypertension and ulcerative colitis, which was diagnosed via colonoscopy 5 years ago. Current medications include lisinopril and rectal mesalamine. He is sexually active with two female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus and multiple excoriations on the trunk and extremities. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.5 g/dL


Leukocyte count
7500/mm3



Platelet count
280,000/mm3



Serum



 Na+

138 mEq/L


 Cl-

101 mEq/L


 K+

4.7 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
18 mg/dL


 Glucose
91 mg/dL


 Creatinine
0.8 mg/dL


 Bilirubin



 Total
1.5 mg/dL


 Direct

0.9 mg/dL


 Alkaline phosphatase

460 U/L


 AST
75 U/L


 ALT
78 U/L


 Antinuclear antibody
negative


 Antimitochondrial antibodies
negative


An endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) has an insidious onset in most patients but can also manifest with fatigue, scleral icterus, and increased serum transaminase concentrations and is associated with ulcerative colitis. However, AIH is usually associated with the presence of antinuclear antibodies, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is more frequent in men, in contrast to other autoimmune hepatobiliary diseases. PSC is usually asymptomatic in earlier stages; patients develop pruritus, jaundice, elevated parameters of cholestasis (e.g., alkaline phosphatase, conjugated bilirubin), and wall thickening and irregular diameter of the bile ducts on ultrasonography as the disease progresses. PSC is classically associated with ulcerative colitis. Magnetic resonance imaging and endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography are the recommended imaging modalities for diagnosing PSC.
Image Description:

Overview illustration comparing clinical features, epidemiology, pathophysiology, and diagnostics of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), and autoimmune hepatitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) typically manifests with fatigue, pruritus, scleral icterus, and elevated parameters of cholestasis (e.g., alkaline phosphatase, conjugated bilirubin). However, PBC is associated with the presence of antimitochondrial antibodies in > 95% of cases, which this patient does not have. In addition, this condition mostly affects women and is not associated with ulcerative colitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis B in its acute form is asymptomatic in most patients but can cause fatigue and mildly increased serum transaminase concentrations. The patient's sexual history also puts him at increased risk for hepatitis B. However, hepatitis B does not cause thickening of the bile ducts or focal bile duct dilatation on ultrasonography, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

IgG4-associated cholangitis can cause fatigue, pruritus, scleral icterus, and elevated parameters of cholestasis (e.g., alkaline phosphatase, conjugated bilirubin). However, this condition is almost always associated with concurrent autoimmune pancreatitis, which would manifest with recurrent episodes of upper abdominal tenderness.
questions.hint: The ERCP shows thickening and beading of the bile ducts and multifocal bile duct dilatation.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man comes to the physician with a 1-week history of yellowish discoloration of his eyes, generalized fatigue, and pruritus. He was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis 7 years ago. At the time of diagnosis, a pANCA test was also positive. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and multiple scratch marks on the trunk and extremities. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Serum studies show a total bilirubin concentration of 3.2 mg/dL, direct bilirubin concentration of 2.5 mg/dL, and alkaline phosphatase level of 450 U/L. Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography shows focal areas of intrahepatic bile duct strictures alternating with areas of dilation. Microscopic examination of a liver biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Periportal lymphocytic infiltration and piecemeal necrosis
Irregular ductal glands lined by atypical and pleomorphic cells
Ductopenia and fibrotic degeneration of periportal hepatocytes

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's symptoms, laboratory, and imaging studies are consistent with the diagnosis of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). In 90% of cases, this condition is associated with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), usually ulcerative colitis, which this patient has. Histopathological examination of bile ducts would typically show periductal concentric scarring and fibrosis that are consistent with the characteristic onion-skin appearance. PSC, which is classically seen in middle-aged men, increases the risk of development of cancer of the gallbladder and cholangiocarcinoma (10–15% of cases). Perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (pANCA) are not specific to PSC but can be present in up to 80% of cases.
Image Description:

Overview illustration comparing clinical features, epidemiology, pathophysiology, and diagnostics of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), and autoimmune hepatitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Periportal lymphocytic infiltration and piecemeal necrosis can be seen in various conditions that cause fulminant liver failure, e.g., autoimmune hepatitis. Although fulminant liver failure can cause hyperbilirubinemia and jaundice, as seen here, coagulopathy, hepatic encephalopathy, and elevated serum ALT and AST levels (usually in the 1000 U/L range) would also be expected. Moreover, this would not explain alternating intrahepatic bile duct strictures, which is a characteristic finding of PSC.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

A chronic inflammatory infiltrate (blue overlay) consisting of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and eosinophilic granulocytes can be seen in the center of the image. The infiltrate is located at the interface of the portal tract and hepatic lobules (yellow overlay), which is referred to as “interface hepatitis.”

These features are typical of chronic hepatitis, in this case, hepatitis B. Chronic inflammation of any tissue typically shows mononuclear cell infiltration (e.g., lymphocytes, plasma cells, macrophages) and fibrosis may be present simultaneously as well (not present here).

C) INCORRECT:

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency can cause an accumulation of misfolded PAS-positive globules and fibrosis within the hepatocytes. Elevated parameters of cholestasis, hyperbilirubinemia, and elevated alkaline phosphatase are not common features of α1-antitrypsin deficiency-mediated hepatic cirrhosis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver biopsy specimen (PAS diastase stain; approx. 450x magnification)

PAS-positive and diastase-resistant globular cytoplasmic inclusions (green overlay) can be seen within periportal hepatocytes. The periportal fibrous tissue has been highlighted for orientation (white overlay).

These are the characteristic histopathological findings in alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. Additional immunohistochemical staining should be performed to confirm that the inclusions contain alpha-1 antitrypsin.

D) INCORRECT:

Irregular ductal glands lined by atypical and pleomorphic cells on histologic examination is consistent with intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma, a rare type of cancer of the bile ducts. Although this condition can also cause obstructive jaundice and elevated ALP, as seen here, patients with cholangiocarcinoma are more likely asymptomatic. Other symptoms that would suggest this diagnosis, such as hepatomegaly, a painless palpable gallbladder (Courvoisier's sign), and nonspecific B symptoms (e.g., weight loss, nausea), are also lacking.

While PSC can increase the risk of cholangiocarcinoma, the finding of alternating intrahepatic bile duct strictures on MRCP is uncommon.

E) INCORRECT:

Fibrotic degeneration of periportal hepatocytes and ductopenia are characteristic late histopathologic findings of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC). In the early stages, lymphocytic infiltration of portal areas and periductal granulomas would be expected. PBC may present with pruritus, hyperbilirubinemia, and elevated alkaline phosphatase, just like this patient. However, PBC does not cause alternating intrahepatic bile duct strictures. Moreover, PBC would be associated with the development of antimitochondrial autoantibodies, not pANCA.
questions.hint: This patient with ulcerative colitis has pruritus, icterus, elevated parameters of cholestasis, and alternating strictures and dilation on MRCP (beading pattern). A well-known cause of cholestatic jaundice in patients with autoimmune diseases, particularly ulcerative colitis, is primary sclerosing cholangitis.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of increasing fatigue and dark discoloration of urine. Medical history is remarkable for ulcerative colitis. Current medications include oral sulfasalazine and topical budesonide. Immunizations are up-to-date. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years and does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. He is sexually active with two female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 122/84 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus. Abdominal examination discloses mild right upper quadrant tenderness. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:


Bilirubin



 Total

2.3 mg/dL


 Direct

1.5 mg/dL


Alkaline phosphatase
420 U/L


ALT
82 U/L


Hepatitis B surface antigen antibody
positive


Perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies
positive


Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) confirms the diagnosis of an active hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. An acute HBV infection, though asymptomatic in most cases, may manifest with fatigue, jaundice, and mildly elevated transaminases, as seen here. The patient's sexual history also puts him at increased risk of HBV infection. However, the positive hepatitis B surface antigen antibodies (anti-HBs) indicate that he is either vaccinated or has had an HBV infection in the past, making an active HBV infection an unlikely diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

A contrast-enhanced abdominal CT scan can be used in the diagnostic workup of patients with cholestasis and helps to differentiate intrahepatic from extrahepatic causes. However, this patient's underlying condition cannot be confirmed by a CT scan, because visible findings (e.g., irregular diameter of the bile duct, diffuse thickening of the wall of the common hepatic and bile ducts) would be unspecific.

C) CORRECT:

Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) and endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) are the imaging modalities of choice for confirming primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). These tests typically show multifocal strictures alternating with dilation, as well as beading of both intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts (pearl necklace sign). As a result of the bile duct obstruction in PSC, patients develop cholestasis. Liver biopsy, although not routinely indicated, can further support the diagnosis and typically shows “onion skin” scarring and fibrosis of bile ducts.
Image Description:

Overview illustration comparing clinical features, epidemiology, pathophysiology, and diagnostics of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), and autoimmune hepatitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Testing for antimitochondrial antibodies (AMAs) is highly sensitive and specific for primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), with AMAs found in more than 95% of individuals with this condition. PBC often manifests with fatigue, jaundice, and elevated cholestasis parameters (ALP, direct bilirubin), as seen in this patient. However, PBC is much more common in women and is not associated with ulcerative colitis or positive pANCAs.

E) INCORRECT:

Abdominal ultrasonography can be used in the diagnostic workup of patients with cholestasis and helps to distinguish between intrahepatic and extrahepatic causes. This patient's underlying condition, however, cannot be confirmed by an abdominal ultrasound, because visible findings (e.g., irregular diameter of the bile duct, diffuse thickening of the wall of the common hepatic and bile ducts) would be unspecific.
questions.hint: This patient's condition typically affects middle-aged men, manifests with right upper quadrant tenderness and cholestasis (chronic fatigue, scleral icterus, dark urine, elevated cholestatic parameters), and is associated with positive pANCAs (approx. 80% of cases) and inflammatory bowel disease (up to 90% of cases), particularly ulcerative colitis.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man is evaluated for fatigue, intermittent hematochezia, and pruritus.
Laboratory testing reveals an international normalized ratio of 1.0, with other results as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
10.6
13.5–17.5


Platelet count (per mm3)
350,000
150,000–350,000



Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter)
90
0–35



Alanine aminotransferase (U/liter)
94
0–35



Alkaline phosphatase (U/liter)
356
30–120


Albumin (g/dL)
4.0
3.5–5.5


Total bilirubin (mg/dL)
0.8
0.3–1.0


Tests for hepatitis B surface antigen, hepatitis C antibody, antimitochondrial antibodies, and antinuclear antibodies are all negative.
An ultrasound of the right upper quadrant shows no evidence of biliary dilation.
Which one of the following tests is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of the hepatic venous pressure gradient

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography is the most appropriate investigation because it is sensitive for this diagnosis, and it avoids the unnecessary risk of iatrogenic cholangitis from endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography and the risk for complications from liver biopsy.

B) INCORRECT:

Right upper quadrant ultrasound may be normal in patients with PSC, particularly if only the intrahepatic ducts are involved. With no evidence of synthetic liver dysfunction or portal hypertension, a hepatic venous pressure gradient measurement or an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy to screen for varices is not needed.

C) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography is the most appropriate investigation because it is sensitive for this diagnosis, and it avoids the unnecessary risk of iatrogenic cholangitis from endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography and the risk for complications from liver biopsy.

D) CORRECT:

A cholestatic biochemical profile with a normal ultrasound of the right upper quadrant suggests intrahepatic cholestasis, which can be seen with primary biliary cirrhosis, viral hepatitis, cholestasis of pregnancy, and certain infiltrative diseases. Given that all these conditions have been ruled out by this patient’s history and laboratory testing, primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is the leading differential diagnosis.

PSC is a chronic liver disease characterized by inflammation and fibrosis of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts. It occurs most commonly in men, with a mean age of 40 years at diagnosis. Individuals with PSC have laboratory testing consistent with a cholestatic biochemical profile and rarely have antimitochondrial antibodies. Imaging typically demonstrates multifocal stricturing and segmental dilatations. Up to 80% of patients with PSC have concomitant inflammatory bowel disease, particularly ulcerative colitis, consistent with the patient’s report of hematochezia.

Key learning point: The most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis of primary sclerosing cholangitis is magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography.

E) INCORRECT:

Right upper quadrant ultrasound may be normal in patients with PSC, particularly if only the intrahepatic ducts are involved. With no evidence of synthetic liver dysfunction or portal hypertension, a hepatic venous pressure gradient measurement or an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy to screen for varices is not needed.

He has ulcerative colitis, which was diagnosed via colonoscopy 5 years ago, and is currently treated with rectal mesalamine. Examination shows scleral icterus and multiple excoriations on the trunk and extremities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Laboratory studies show:


Leukocyte count
7500/mm3



Serum

1.5 mg/dL

0.9 mg/dL

460 U/L

75 U/L

78 U/L


 Antinuclear antibody
negative


 Antimitochondrial antibodies
negative


An endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) shows thickening and beading of the bile ducts and multifocal bile duct dilatation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) has an insidious onset in most patients but can also manifest with fatigue, scleral icterus, and increased serum transaminase concentrations and is associated with ulcerative colitis. However, AIH is usually associated with the presence of antinuclear antibodies, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this patient.

Overview illustration comparing clinical features, epidemiology, pathophysiology, and diagnostics of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), and autoimmune hepatitis.

C) INCORRECT:

In addition, this condition mostly affects women and is not associated with ulcerative colitis.

D) INCORRECT:

However, this condition is almost always associated with concurrent autoimmune pancreatitis, which would manifest with recurrent episodes of upper abdominal tenderness.

A 41-year-old man comes to the office because of a 2-month history of increasing fatigue and dark discoloration of urine. Medical history is remarkable for ulcerative colitis. Current medications include oral sulfasalazine and topical budesonide. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 122/84 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus. Abdominal examination discloses mild right upper quadrant tenderness. Serum studies show:


Bilirubin



 Total
2.3 mg/dL


 Direct

1.5 mg/dL


Alkaline phosphatase
420 U/L


ALT
82 U/L


Hepatitis B surface antigen antibody
positive


Perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies
positive


Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) confirms the diagnosis of an active hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. An acute HBV infection, though asymptomatic in most cases, may manifest with fatigue, jaundice, and mildly elevated transaminases, as seen here. However, the positive hepatitis B surface antigen antibodies (anti-HBs) indicate that he is either vaccinated or has had an HBV infection in the past, making an active HBV infection an unlikely diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

A contrast-enhanced abdominal CT scan can be used in the diagnostic workup of patients with cholestasis and helps to differentiate intrahepatic from extrahepatic causes. However, this patient's underlying condition cannot be confirmed by a CT scan, because visible findings (e.g., irregular diameter of the bile duct, diffuse thickening of the wall of the common hepatic and bile ducts) would be unspecific.

Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) and endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) are the imaging modalities of choice for confirming primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). These tests typically show multifocal strictures alternating with dilation, as well as beading of both intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts (pearl necklace sign). As a result of the bile duct obstruction in PSC, patients develop cholestasis. Liver biopsy, although not routinely indicated, can further support the diagnosis and typically shows “onion skin” scarring and fibrosis of bile ducts.
Image Description:

Overview illustration comparing clinical features, epidemiology, pathophysiology, and diagnostics of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), and autoimmune hepatitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Testing for antimitochondrial antibodies (AMAs) is highly sensitive and specific for primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), with AMAs found in more than 95% of individuals with this condition. PBC often manifests with fatigue, jaundice, and elevated cholestasis parameters (ALP, direct bilirubin), as seen in this patient. However, PBC is much more common in women and is not associated with ulcerative colitis or positive pANCAs.

Abdominal ultrasonography can be used in the diagnostic workup of patients with cholestasis and helps to distinguish between intrahepatic and extrahepatic causes. This patient's underlying condition, however, cannot be confirmed by an abdominal ultrasound, because visible findings (e.g., irregular diameter of the bile duct, diffuse thickening of the wall of the common hepatic and bile ducts) would be unspecific.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of progressive fatigue, pruritus, and intermittent right upper quadrant pain. He occasionally notices pale stools. He has a 9-year history of ulcerative colitis, controlled with 5-aminosalicylic acid. He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Physical examination shows mild hepatomegaly (see lab results and report)


Test
Result
Normal Values



Total bilirubin
45 μmol/L
3.5 - 16.5 μmol/L


Alkaline phosphatase
540 IU/L
39 - 117 IU/L


Gamma glutamyltransferase
142 IU/L
6 - 37 IU/L


Antimitochondrial antibodies
Negative
< 1:20



MRCP: Multiple short, irregular strictures affecting both intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts, with intervening focal dilatations
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mirizzi syndrome is a rare complication of gallstone disease in which the extrahepatic bile duct is compressed by a gallstone at the neck of the gall bladder or the cystic duct. This condition manifests with features of cholestasis, but imaging would show a narrowing of the common hepatic duct with dilation of the gall bladder and intrahepatic biliary tree.

B) INCORRECT:

Primary biliary cholangitis manifests with features of cholestatic liver disease but typically occurs in middle-aged women and is associated with positive antimitochondrial antibodies. Moreover, it involves immune-mediated destruction of only the intrahepatic bile ducts.

C) INCORRECT:

Biliary atresia, which is a congenital biliary tract malformation, manifests with features of cholestasis, but the symptoms of this condition typically appear during the neonatal period. Moreover, this condition is associated with obliteration of the extrahepatic biliary system and gallbladder without focal dilation of the biliary tree.

D) CORRECT:

Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is associated with ulcerative colitis through an immunologically driven mechanism, leading to progressive ductal scarring and impaired bile flow. This condition manifests with progressive fatigue, pruritus, and right upper quadrant pain. Laboratory findings show elevated alkaline phosphatase, elevated gamma-glutamyl transferase, and mild hyperbilirubinemia, indicating cholestasis. Imaging reveals multiple short, irregular strictures with intervening focal dilatations, known as the 'beading' pattern, affecting both intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts. Atypical perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (pANCA) are present in up to 80% of patients with PSC. Antimitochondrial antibodies are usually negative; their presence supports a diagnosis of primary biliary cholangitis.

Key learning point: Primary sclerosing cholangitis is characterized by multiple strictures in the intra- and extra-hepatic bile ducts and is often associated with inflammatory bowel disease, such as ulcerative colitis.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man presents for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well and has no significant past medical history. He does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Physical examination shows no abnormalities (see lab results and reports).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Hemoglobin
115 g/L
130 - 170 g/L


WBC
8.3 x 109/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 109/L


Total bilirubin
3.6 μmol/L
3.5 - 16.5 μmol/L


Alkaline phosphatase
293 IU/L
39 - 117 IU/L


Alanine aminotransferase
35 IU/L
5 - 40 IU/L




MRCP: Multiple strictures in the intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts
Serology: Positive for atypical p-ANCA

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The patient's laboratory findings of cholestasis (e.g., elevated alkaline phosphatase), presence of atypical p-ANCA antibodies, and MRCP findings of bile duct strictures are consistent with primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). PSC is strongly associated with inflammatory bowel disease, particularly ulcerative colitis, which may be asymptomatic in the early stages and present with subtle features like anemia due to occult gastrointestinal bleeding. Colonoscopy is crucial for diagnosing underlying inflammatory bowel disease and for colorectal cancer surveillance, given the increased risk in PSC patients. Colonoscopy is indicated at the time of PSC diagnosis and then every 1–2 years in patients with inflammatory bowel disease. Management of PSC is mainly supportive and includes measures such as treating cholestasis-associated pruritus with cholestyramine, relieving symptomatic obstruction with dilation or stent placement via ERCP, and monitoring for complications. For severe disease, liver transplantation is the only curative treatment but has a significant risk of disease recurrence.

Key learning point: In cases of primary sclerosing cholangitis, a colonoscopy is important to evaluate for associated inflammatory bowel disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Liver biopsy is not routinely indicated as part of the workup for primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) and is only considered in patients with normal imaging findings despite persistently elevated cholestatic enzymes or if an autoimmune hepatitis-PSC overlap syndrome is suspected. The characteristic biopsy findings of PSC is concentric periductal onion skin fibrosis, but the biopsy may not reliably sample the patchy fibrotic changes seen in bile duct disorders. The imaging findings and serology provide sufficient diagnostic information without the need for invasive tissue sampling.

C) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is not used to diagnose primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) unless therapeutic intervention for biliary obstruction is needed or MRI (for MCRP) is contraindicated. ERCP with balloon dilation is reserved for patients with severe strictures causing symptoms due to significant biliary obstruction (e.g., pruritis) or cholangitis. ERCP itself carries risks such as pancreatitis and cholangitis. The patient does not exhibit acute obstructive symptoms or severe complications requiring urgent intervention.

D) INCORRECT:

CA 19-9 is a tumor marker that can be elevated in cholangiocarcinoma but is not specific and can be raised in benign conditions like cholestasis. The patient's presentation and imaging findings suggest a biliary pathology rather than malignancy. Without evidence of a dominant mass or rapid clinical deterioration, CA 19-9 measurement does not clarify the diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-month history of increasing generalized fatigue and severe pruritus. He has a history of ulcerative colitis diagnosed by colonoscopy 5 years ago and is currently treated with rectal mesalamine. On examination, you note scleral icterus and multiple excoriations on the trunk and extremities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Laboratory studies show:


White blood cell (WBC) count, blood
7.5 × 109/L (3.5–10.5)


Bilirubin, total, blood
26 μmol/L (3–17)


Bilirubin, direct (conjugated), blood
15 μmol/L (2–9)


Alkaline phosphatase, blood

460 IU/L (50–136)


Aspartate aminotransferase (AST), blood
75 IU/L (15–37)


Alanine aminotransferase (ALT), blood
78 IU/L (17–63)


Antinuclear antibody
Negative


Antimitochondrial antibodies
Negative


An endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) shows thickening and beading of the bile ducts and multifocal bile duct dilatation. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) has an insidious onset in most patients but can also manifest with fatigue, scleral icterus, and increased serum transaminase concentrations and is associated with ulcerative colitis. However, AIH is usually associated with the presence of antinuclear antibodies, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

IgG4-associated cholangitis can cause fatigue, pruritus, scleral icterus, and elevated parameters of cholestasis (e.g., alkaline phosphatase, conjugated bilirubin). However, this condition is almost always associated with concurrent autoimmune pancreatitis, which would manifest with recurrent episodes of upper abdominal tenderness.

C) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis B in its acute form is asymptomatic in most patients but can cause fatigue and mildly increased serum transaminase concentrations. However, hepatitis B does not cause thickening of the bile ducts or focal bile duct dilatation on ultrasonography, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) typically manifests with fatigue, pruritus, scleral icterus, and elevated parameters of cholestasis (e.g., alkaline phosphatase, conjugated bilirubin). However, PBC is associated with the presence of antimitochondrial antibodies in > 95% of cases, which this patient does not have. In addition, this condition mostly affects women and is not associated with ulcerative colitis.

E) CORRECT:

Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is more frequent in men, in contrast to other autoimmune hepatobiliary diseases. PSC is usually asymptomatic in earlier stages; patients develop pruritus, jaundice, elevated parameters of cholestasis (e.g., alkaline phosphatase, conjugated bilirubin), and wall thickening and irregular diameter of the bile ducts on ultrasonography as the disease progresses. PSC is classically associated with ulcerative colitis. Magnetic resonance imaging and endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography are the recommended imaging modalities for diagnosing PSC.

Key learning point: Primary sclerosing cholangitis presents with cholestatic liver enzyme elevation, pruritus, and is strongly associated with ulcerative colitis and characteristic bile duct beading on imaging.
Image Description:

Overview illustration comparing clinical features, epidemiology, pathophysiology, and diagnostics of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), and autoimmune hepatitis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with a 7-year history of ulcerative colitis presents with 4 weeks of progressive fatigue and intermittent pruritus. She reports her last colonoscopy 6 months ago showed stable mild pancolitis. Current medications include mesalamine and daily multivitamins. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows mild scleral icterus without abdominal tenderness, hepatomegaly, or splenomegaly. Laboratory studies show alkaline phosphatase 340 U/L, gamma-glutamyltransferase 215 U/L, ALT 88 U/L, AST 72 U/L, total bilirubin 3.2 mg/dL, and conjugated bilirubin 2.4 mg/dL. The patient's ulcerative colitis has been clinically stable without recent flares. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Refer to hepatology for suspected primary sclerosing cholangitis
Perform hepatitis A, B, and C serologies
Order antimitochondrial antibodies and anti-smooth muscle antibodies
Increase mesalamine dose and monitor liver enzymes in 1 week

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Significant cholestatic enzyme elevation in a patient with inflammatory bowel disease raises suspicion for primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). While referral to hepatology for workup and management of suspected PSC is appropriate, immediate imaging to evaluate for biliary obstruction is indicated first.

B) INCORRECT:

While viral hepatitis serologies are part of a comprehensive liver evaluation, viral hepatitis does not typically cause this degree of elevation in cholestatic enzymes in the absence of a more significant elevation in hepatocellular enzymes. Another step in management is more appropriate.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- Clinical and laboratory evidence of cholestasis in a patient with ulcerative colitis raises concern for primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), which occurs in approximately 5% of patients with inflammatory bowel disease. The diagnostic approach involves abdominal ultrasound to evaluate for biliary obstruction, followed by specialist referral for advanced imaging (e.g., magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography) and ongoing management.

D) INCORRECT:

Antimitochondrial antibodies are associated with primary biliary cholangitis, and anti-smooth muscle antibodies suggest autoimmune hepatitis. While autoantibodies may be obtained during hepatology workup, they are not the immediate next step. Initial imaging to exclude obstruction takes priority over serological testing.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's ulcerative colitis symptoms are stable, which makes medication adjustment inappropriate, and increasing the dose of mesalamine does not address the underlying cholestatic process. The cholestatic enzyme pattern indicates a need for immediate evaluation for biliary pathology rather than symptomatic treatment of the underlying inflammatory bowel disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of worsening fatigue and generalized itching. He also reports occasional episodes of right upper quadrant abdominal pain, which he describes as dull and constant. His medical history includes ulcerative colitis diagnosed 10 years ago, currently well-controlled with mesalamine. Family history is unremarkable. He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. He appears jaundiced with excoriations on his arms and legs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination shows mild hepatomegaly without tenderness. Laboratory studies show a total bilirubin concentration of 3.8 mg/dL, direct bilirubin concentration of 2.9 mg/dL, serum alkaline phosphatase concentration of 450 U/L, and serum alanine aminotransferase concentration of 80 U/L. Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography shows multifocal strictures and dilatations of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Management of PSC is primarily supportive and includes medications to manage associated symptoms (e.g., pruritus), interventional treatment as needed to relieve biliary obstructions, and monitoring for commonly associated conditions and complications. Accumulation of bile acids in the skin is the primary cause of pruritus in PSC. Cholestyramine binds to bile acids in the intestine, preventing absorption into the bloodstream. This promotes bile acid excretion, which reduces pruritus.

There are currently no medications that prevent disease progression. Ursodeoxycholic acid is widely used, but evidence of benefit is mixed. Liver transplantation is the only curative treatment, but it carries a significant risk of disease recurrence and is therefore reserved for patients with decompensated cirrhosis or intractable symptoms unresponsive to medical therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Biliary stenting is indicated for symptomatic severe dominant strictures in PSC that cause significant cholestasis, jaundice, or cholangitis. This intervention is not routinely performed for diffuse disease or isolated pruritus without obstructive symptoms or cholangitis. It is not an appropriate step in management for most PSC patients.

C) INCORRECT:

Liver transplantation is the only definitive treatment for advanced PSC with end-stage liver disease or complications such as recurrent cholangitis or hepatic failure. Since there is a significant risk for disease recurrence even after liver transplantation, this treatment is reserved for patients with decompensated cirrhosis or intractable symptoms unresponsive to medical therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Azathioprine is an immunosuppressant used in autoimmune hepatitis and as maintenance therapy in inflammatory bowel disease. It does not alter the course of PSC or relieve symptoms. Immunosuppressants are ineffective except in patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis-autoimmune hepatitis overlap syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Prednisone is a glucocorticoid used as first-line therapy for autoimmune hepatitis and the induction of remission in ulcerative colitis flares. It is ineffective in the treatment of PSC, which is unresponsive to immunosuppressants.
questions.hint: Cholestatic jaundice with multifocal intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile duct strictures and dilatations suggests primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC).
